User Story: As a player, I want to read clearly formatted narrative text so I can immerse myself in the story
Acceptance Criteria:
The NarrativeDisplay component renders text with clear paragraph breaks
The display automatically scrolls to show the latest content
Text is formatted with appropriate spacing and margins
Font size is readable on all screen sizes
Text updates smoothly when new content is added
Technical Requirements: The system must display narrative text with proper formatting including paragraph breaks and appropriate spacing. It must automatically scroll to show the latest content as it's added. The text display must be responsive for different screen sizes and update smoothly when new content appears
Implementation Considerations: Consider the balance between simplicity and richness in text formatting. Think about the scrolling behavior and when it should occur automatically versus allowing user control. The display should maintain readability while creating an immersive reading experience

User Story: As a player, I want to distinguish between narrative text and character dialogue so I can follow conversations
Acceptance Criteria:
Dialogue is visually distinct from narrative description
Different speakers are clearly identified when possible
Formatting is consistent throughout the narrative
Dialogue stands out visually on the page
The distinction works on all screen sizes
Technical Requirements: The system must visually distinguish dialogue from narrative description. It must identify different speakers when possible and maintain consistent formatting throughout the narrative. Dialogue must stand out visually on the page, and this distinction must work on all screen sizes
Implementation Considerations: Consider different visual approaches to distinguish dialogue (styling, indentation, etc.) that maintain readability. Think about how to identify speakers consistently when that information is available. The visual distinction should enhance the narrative while working across all device sizes

User Story: As a player, I want proper text formatting with paragraphs and emphasis so it's easy to read
Acceptance Criteria:
Text formatting (emphasis, etc.) is rendered correctly
Paragraphs have appropriate spacing between them
Important text elements receive proper emphasis
Formatting is consistent throughout the experience
Content is legible on all supported screen sizes
Technical Requirements: The system must correctly render text formatting including emphasis and paragraph breaks. It must apply appropriate spacing between paragraphs and proper emphasis for important text elements. Formatting must be consistent throughout the experience and remain legible across all supported screen sizes
Implementation Considerations: Consider what formatting capabilities are most important for narrative readability. Think about how to balance rich formatting with performance and cross-device compatibility. The text display should enhance the story without becoming overly complex

User Story: As a player, I want to see clearly presented choices so I can make informed decisions
Acceptance Criteria:
The ChoiceSelector displays 3-4 choices as buttons or cards
Selecting a choice triggers the corresponding narrative action
A text input field allows custom responses when appropriate
Choices are clearly distinguished from each other
Choice text is complete and readable
Technical Requirements: The system must display decision options (typically 3-4 choices) in a clear and accessible format. It must allow players to select choices and trigger the corresponding narrative actions. When appropriate, the system must provide a text input field for custom responses. Choices must be visually distinct and have readable text
Implementation Considerations: Consider what visual presentation (buttons, cards, etc.) best communicates choices to players. Think about the appropriate placement of choices in the interface relative to narrative content. The choice presentation should balance prominence with integration into the overall game experience

User Story: As a player, I want visual feedback when selecting a choice so I know my selection was registered
Acceptance Criteria:
Choices have hover/focus states for visual feedback
The selected choice is highlighted when chosen
There is a visual transition when a choice is selected
The interface provides clear confirmation of selection
Visual feedback is consistent across all choice components
Technical Requirements: The system must provide visual feedback for choice interaction including hover and focus states. It must highlight selected choices and provide a visual transition when choices are selected. The feedback must clearly confirm selection and be consistent across all choice components
Implementation Considerations: Consider what visual indicators best communicate different interaction states (hover, focus, selected). Think about transition effects that provide clear feedback without delaying the narrative flow. The feedback design should be intuitive and enhance the feeling of interactivity

User Story: As a player, I want choices to be disabled while the AI generates content so I don't make inadvertent selections
Acceptance Criteria:
Choices are visibly disabled during AI processing
The disabled state is clearly indicated visually
Attempting to click disabled choices has no effect
Choices are automatically re-enabled when AI completes
Transition between enabled and disabled states is smooth
Technical Requirements: The system must visibly disable choice options during AI content generation. The disabled state must be clearly indicated visually and prevent interaction. Choices must be automatically re-enabled when AI processing completes, with smooth transitions between states
Implementation Considerations: Consider how to clearly communicate the disabled state while maintaining a cohesive visual design. Think about transition effects that make the state change evident but not jarring. The disabled state should communicate that the system is working rather than simply blocking interaction

User Story: As a player, I want to see my character's basic information during gameplay so I can remember who I'm playing
Acceptance Criteria:
The CharacterSummary displays the character's name and description
Basic character status information is visible
Character information is accessible throughout gameplay
The display is unobtrusive but easily referenced
Information updates if character status changes
Technical Requirements: The system must display basic character information (name, description, key stats) during gameplay. This information must be accessible throughout the game session while remaining unobtrusive. The display must update automatically if character data changes
Implementation Considerations: Consider what character information is most important to display during gameplay versus what can be accessed through more detailed views. Think about placement that balances visibility with minimal disruption to the narrative experience. The character summary should provide context without overwhelming the interface

User Story: As a player, I want to collapse or expand the character panel so I can focus on the narrative when desired
Acceptance Criteria:
The character panel can be collapsed and expanded
The collapsed state maximizes narrative display space
The state persists during the session
The panel automatically collapses on smaller screens
Collapse/expand control is intuitive and accessible
Technical Requirements: The system must provide a collapsible character panel that users can expand or collapse as needed. The panel's state must persist during the session and automatically collapse on smaller screens. The collapse/expand control must be intuitive and accessible
Implementation Considerations: Consider the most effective collapse/expand interaction and icon that clearly communicates its purpose. Think about how the layout should adjust when the panel is collapsed to maximize narrative space. The responsive behavior should prioritize content appropriately based on screen size

User Story: As a player, I want to know when my game is being saved so I don't lose progress
Acceptance Criteria:
The UI displays the last saved timestamp
Auto-save events show a visual indicator
Save status is clearly visible in the interface
Failed saves trigger a notification
The indicator doesn't disrupt the gameplay experience
Technical Requirements: The system must display the timestamp of the last successful save. It must show a visual indicator during auto-save operations and notify users of failed saves. Save status information must be clearly visible without disrupting gameplay
Implementation Considerations: Consider how to display save status information in a way that provides confidence without being distracting. Think about the appropriate level of detail for timestamps and status indicators. The save feedback system should reassure users without interrupting their narrative experience

User Story: As a player, I want to manually save my game when reaching important points
Acceptance Criteria:
A manual save button is readily accessible
Successful saves provide visual confirmation
The save button is disabled during processing
Save failures show appropriate error messages
The manual save doesn't interrupt gameplay flow
Technical Requirements: The system must provide an accessible button for manual game saving. It must disable the save button during processing, provide visual confirmation of successful saves, and display appropriate error messages for save failures. The manual save process must not interrupt gameplay flow
Implementation Considerations: Consider the optimal placement for the save button that makes it easily accessible without being accidentally triggered. Think about appropriate feedback that confirms saves without being disruptive. The save functionality should provide peace of mind while maintaining immersion

User Story: As a player, I want to exit the game safely with my progress saved
Acceptance Criteria:
An exit button is clearly accessible
Exiting prompts for confirmation before leaving
The game state is saved before exiting
The exit process is responsive and quick
Exiting returns to an appropriate menu or screen
Technical Requirements: The system must provide an accessible method for exiting the game. It must prompt for confirmation before exiting, save the game state, and navigate to an appropriate destination screen. The exit process must be responsive and preserve user progress
Implementation Considerations: Consider the optimal placement for the exit control to ensure accessibility without encouraging accidental exits. Think about appropriate confirmation messaging that clearly communicates what will happen. The exit process should balance data safety with minimal user friction

User Story: As a player, I want to recover from unexpected crashes without losing significant progress
Acceptance Criteria:
The system automatically recovers session state after crashes
Recovery restores the most recent saved state
Progress loss is minimized to a few minutes at most
Recovery options are presented when needed
The recovery process is transparent to the user
Technical Requirements: The system must detect whether a previous session ended abnormally and attempt to recover from the most recent saved state. It must present appropriate recovery options to the user and handle potential errors during recovery. Progress loss must be minimized to maintain user trust
Implementation Considerations: Consider the balance between automatic recovery and user control after a crash occurs. Think about how frequently the system should save state to minimize potential data loss. The recovery experience should be transparent to users while providing them with clear options

User Story: As a player, I want to be able to resume my game session exactly where I left off
Acceptance Criteria:
The session resumes from the last saved state
Narrative context and choices are restored correctly
Character information is preserved accurately
Session history is accessible and complete
Resume feels seamless with minimal disruption
Technical Requirements: The system must correctly restore all relevant game state components when resuming a session. It must preserve narrative context, player choices, character information, and session history. The resume process must be seamless with minimal disruption to the player experience
Implementation Considerations: Consider what state information is most critical for maintaining narrative continuity when resuming. Think about the loading experience and how to make it feel seamless to the user. The resume functionality should prioritize preserving the player's sense of immersion and story continuity

User Story: As a player, I want to see when the AI is generating content so I know to wait
Acceptance Criteria:
A loading indicator displays during AI content generation
The indicator is visually prominent without being distracting
Loading state prevents premature user interactions
The indicator gives sense of progress, not just waiting
Loading animations are smooth and performant
Technical Requirements: The system must visually indicate when AI content generation is in progress. It must prevent premature user interactions during loading. The loading indicator must be visually prominent without being distracting and should convey a sense of progress rather than just waiting
Implementation Considerations: Consider what visual approach best communicates loading status while maintaining the game's atmosphere. Think about the appropriate balance of prominence versus distraction. The loading indicator should help manage user expectations about wait times while fitting within the overall experience

User Story: As a player, I want friendly error messages when issues occur so I understand what happened
Acceptance Criteria:
Error messages use non-technical, friendly language
Errors appear in a consistent, recognizable format
Messages suggest possible actions when appropriate
Critical errors are visually distinct from warnings
Error display doesn't disrupt the interface layout
Technical Requirements: The system must display error messages in user-friendly, non-technical language. Error messages must appear in a consistent format, suggest possible actions when appropriate, and visually distinguish between severity levels. The error display must not disrupt the interface layout
Implementation Considerations: Consider how to translate technical errors into user-friendly messages without losing important information. Think about where and how errors should be displayed based on their severity and actionability. The error handling should balance informativeness with maintaining a positive user experience

User Story: As a player, I want the option to retry after errors so I can continue playing
Acceptance Criteria:
Retry options are presented for recoverable errors
Retry button is clearly visible and accessible
Multiple retry attempts are supported when appropriate
System provides feedback during retry attempts
Persistent failures offer alternative solutions
Technical Requirements: The system must distinguish between recoverable and non-recoverable errors. For recoverable errors, it must provide a clear retry option. The system must support multiple retry attempts when appropriate, provide feedback during retry attempts, and offer alternative solutions for persistent failures
Implementation Considerations: Consider the appropriate criteria for determining which errors are retryable. Think about how to communicate retry status and progress to users. The retry functionality should degrade gracefully when multiple attempts fail, offering users alternative paths to continue rather than repeatedly encountering the same error

User Story: As a player, I want clear visual feedback for all interactions so I know my actions are registered
Acceptance Criteria:
All interactive elements provide visual feedback on interaction
Button presses have clear visual states (pressed, active, etc.)
Form inputs show focus and active states
System actions provide completion indicators
Feedback is consistent across all interface elements
Technical Requirements: The system must provide consistent visual feedback for all interactive elements. Interactive elements must display appropriate visual states for different interaction modes (hover, focus, pressed, etc.). System actions must provide clear completion indicators. Visual feedback must be consistent across all interface components
Implementation Considerations: Consider what visual feedback is most effective for different types of interactions. Think about the appropriate timing and animation for feedback to be noticeable without being distracting. The feedback system should enhance user confidence while maintaining a cohesive visual experience

User Story: As a player, I want to know my current location in the narrative so I have context for my actions
Acceptance Criteria:
The location indicator shows current narrative location
Location updates are reflected promptly
Location indicator is consistently placed in the interface
Location context helps orient the player
Location display is subtle but accessible
Technical Requirements: The system must display the current narrative location to provide context for player actions. It must update location information promptly when changes occur. The location indicator must be consistently placed in the interface and be subtle yet accessible
Implementation Considerations: Consider where location information is most valuable in the interface without being obtrusive. Think about how detailed location information should be to orient players without overwhelming them. The location display should enhance story immersion while providing necessary context

User Story: As a player with a keyboard, I want full keyboard navigation so I can play without a mouse
Acceptance Criteria:
All interactive elements are navigable using keyboard
Focus states are clearly visible for keyboard navigation
Tab order follows a logical flow through the interface
Keyboard shortcuts are available for common actions
Modal dialogs trap focus appropriately
Technical Requirements: The system must support complete keyboard navigation for all interactive elements. It must display clear focus states for keyboard navigation and follow a logical tab order through the interface. The system must provide keyboard shortcuts for common actions and properly manage focus in modal dialogs
Implementation Considerations: Consider the most intuitive keyboard navigation flow through different sections of the interface. Think about focus visibility that works across different themes while remaining obvious to users. The keyboard navigation should provide equal functionality to mouse interaction without requiring additional steps

User Story: As a player using a screen reader, I want proper ARIA attributes so I can understand the interface
Acceptance Criteria:
Core elements use appropriate ARIA roles and attributes
Dynamic content updates are announced to screen readers
Interactive elements have proper accessible names
Interface structure uses semantic HTML elements
Screen reader testing confirms usability
Technical Requirements: The system must implement proper accessibility features for screen reader users. Core elements must have appropriate ARIA roles and attributes. Dynamic content updates must be announced to screen readers. Interactive elements must have proper accessible names, and the interface must use semantic structure
Implementation Considerations: Consider which dynamic content updates are most important to announce to screen readers. Think about how to make the gaming experience cohesive and enjoyable for non-visual users. The screen reader support should maintain the narrative engagement while providing all necessary interface information

User Story: As a player with visual impairments, I want sufficient color contrast so I can see all interface elements
Acceptance Criteria:
Color contrast meets WCAG AA standards
Text is legible against all backgrounds
Interactive elements are visually distinct
Critical information doesn't rely solely on color
Interface remains usable in high-contrast mode
Technical Requirements: The system must provide sufficient color contrast throughout the interface meeting accessibility standards. Text must be legible against all backgrounds. Interactive elements must be visually distinct without relying solely on color. The interface must remain usable in high-contrast mode
Implementation Considerations: Consider how to balance visual aesthetics with strong contrast requirements. Think about alternative visual indicators beyond color to communicate interactive states and important information. The color design should work for users with various types of color vision deficiencies

User Story: As a player on a mobile device, I want touch-friendly controls so I can play comfortably
Acceptance Criteria:
Touch targets are appropriately sized (minimum 44×44px)
Controls are positioned for comfortable reach
Touch interactions have appropriate feedback
Gestures are used when appropriate and intuitive
The interface adapts to different mobile device sizes
Technical Requirements: The system must provide appropriately sized touch targets for mobile interaction. Controls must be positioned for comfortable reach on touch devices. Touch interactions must have appropriate feedback. The system must implement intuitive gestures where appropriate and adapt to different mobile device sizes
Implementation Considerations: Consider the balance between touch target size and screen space utilization. Think about how hand positioning affects control accessibility on different device sizes. The touch interface should feel natural and responsive while accommodating various user preferences and physical limitations
